posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
We’ve been working on building out as much of our robot code using the simulation features in WPILIB as possible, but recently I’ve discovered that the performance wilding varies depending on the computer used and even PCs that I would consider to be decently powered enough (a gaming laptop) can’t run our robot code simulation very well at all. I cannot tell if this an issue with the simulation or an issue with AdvantageScope. The reason I’m not sure is because when things aren’t working on AdvantageScope all of the data on the simulation GUI is also frozen.

I originally got simulation running on my personal home PC which isn’t exactly new but it’s got decent hardware (i9-10900k, 32GB RAM, 3080 Ti, Win 11). I can run the simulation GUI tool and AdvantageScope without problem using both the 3D field visualizer and the datatables for viewing the data simulated motor outputs/setpoints/etc.

However last night I tried running the exact same code without any changes on my laptop and couldn’t get things working. Specs Dell - G15 15.6" - AMD Ryzen 5 6600H - 8GB Memory - NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3050 - 512GB SSD.

When I checked task manager nothing seemed to be getting overtaxed at all. The simulation would just freeze. I tried pretty much all framerate settings and I went into AdvantageScope and set it nearly all of its possible settings starting at the lowest.

As a last ditch effort we were finally able to get something to work if we just used the Sim GUI by itself and then used it’s internal mechanism tool.

Has anyone else had performance challenges while attempting to simulate code and what tricks have you tried that worked?

If you want to see the code we are trying to sim it’s pretty basic at the moment, but here is the repo.

Contribute to MAikenMagic1102/Crescendo2024 development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: Jordan Miller
posts.cooked:
We’ve been using the same setup, sim + AdvantageScope, on several different laptops, and desktops, including ones that are decently old/less powerful, with no issues.

This is the first year we’ve used AdvantageScope though; in the past we’ve just used the sim and built in mechanism tooling, as you described.

I’ll give your code a run and see if I have any performance issues, but that seems like it’d be rather unusual.  Could you also export your AdvantageScope layout and share it here?

posts.custom_user_title: TBA Dev | 1741 Drive Coach/Mentor | Cranberry Alarm Ri3D

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked: That’s the thing if I setup a single tab in AdvatageScope with only the 3D field window while publishing the robot pose and a mechanism2d to represent the arm, the whole thing completely fails.

posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked: I’m able to simulate just fine in my i3-6100U laptop, although it takes a while to start initially.

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
JohnFogarty:

the whole thing completely fails

It sounds like you’re seeing the entire interface of AdvantageScope freeze completely, rather than just lagging. Is this correct? Are you only seeing this when the 3D field view is open?

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
No, AdvantageScope is not completely frozen its a bit more complicated.

AdvantageScopes interface is not frozen, but all of the simulated data is. Sometimes I will see the pose of the simulated robot teleport around the 3D field or go to places way outside the bounds of where it has ever been told to go.

I’ll have to record some screen grabs of this happening since clearly it’s not a common occurrence.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
